The federal health insurance marketplace will have 40% more call center workers on hand starting Monday to help consumers deal with the final week of Obamacare open enrollment, the Department of Health and Human Services said Wednesday.

Since open enrollment began on Nov.15, nearly 7.5 million consumers selected a plan or were automatically re-enrolled on HealthCare.gov, which is handling enrollment for 37 states, HHS said. When all states are combined, HHS Secretary Sylvia Burwell estimated about 9.9 million people enrolled or were automatically re-enrolled. The rate of sign-ups is expected to accelerate until the Feb. 15 deadline.

Andy Slavitt, principal deputy administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, urged people "not to wait until the last minute" to sign up. For those who do, however, there will be 14,000 call center employees available, up from 10,000 now.
If people are waiting in an online queue for an overloaded website or on hold for the call center at midnight on Feb. 15, Slavitt says, "we'll make sure they get covered."
If not, they will have to wait another year for coverage and will be subject to a penalty on their taxes.

Peak traffic on Healthcare.gov last December was 125,000 people at one time, Slavitt said on a press call. He expects the site to be able to handle more traffic than that this year. The wait time for the call center is down to a "few minutes," he said, adding that the "wait time on the website is zero."

Chicago insurance broker Jordan Wishner said he hasn't been having problems with HealthCare.gov this year, but has had less luck with the call center staff. He worries it won't help if they aren't more knowledgeable about health insurance.

"My biggest complaint is that each staff member knows less than the other," said Wishner, who owns The Health Insurance Shoppe. "They simply do not provide customer service and try to go above and beyond or find resolutions."

The product is better than ever, though, HHS says. In what has become the federal mantra, HealthCare.gov is offering "better prices, more affordability and more options," said Kevin Counihan, HealthCare.gov's CEO.
Besides, Counihan says, "we want people to get the security of health insurance."
Tell us your healthcare story at healthinsurance@usatoday.com

CLEVELAND -- It's Week Three and Day 13 of the trial of Cleveland Police Officer Michael Brelo. It began just after 9 a.m. today (April 22) in front of Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court Judge John P. O'Donnell.
Check back here for constant LIVE updates throughout the day and/or follow WKYC and WKYC's Mike O'Mara on Twitter @wkyc and @MomaraWKYC
4:09 p.m. NOTE: The trial will not resume until 9 a.m. Monday April 27 when O'Donnell will rule on the motion to dismiss the charges at 9 a.m.
4:08 p.m. O'Donnell adjourns court for the day.
3:35 p.m. O'Donnell is still questioning Bell's presentation.
Then he says he will not rule orally on the motion to dismiss today before court adjourns. (Court will not be held on Thursday April 23)
3:14 p.m. Shaughnessy concludes his presentation. Assistant Prosecutor Rick Bell now addresses O'Donnell on the defense motion. He says Shaughnessy counted on causation.
Bell says that because Shaughnessy relied heavily on disputing W. Ken Katsaris's testimony as not on point.

Katsaris is a former police officer/use-of-force expert. He said he has been training police officers for 48 years. Katsaris also submitted a report on the deadly Cleveland police chase. Katsaris testified on Monday. Katsaris maintained that Brelo acted unreasonably when he climbed onto the trunk of a police cruiser and then onto the hood of the Malibu to fire 15 shots into the suspects' car.
3:03 p.m. Judge O'Donnell asks multiple questions of Shaughnessy as Shaughnessy expresses his reasons and the case citations for dismissal.

2:40 p.m. Defense attorney Tom Shaughnessy calls for the judge to dismiss the charges against Brelo according to Rule 29-A, a rule that allows for them to be dismissed because the prosecution has not proved its case nor met its burden of evidence to allow for two counts of voluntary manslaughter.
2:17 p.m. Court resumes as Judge O'Donnell is having the prosecution list its exhibits.

12:41 p.m. The prosecutors rest their case, with the stipulation as the weapons from the Cleveland officers are actually the weapons of those officers. The judge says they will discuss that stipulation after lunch.
Court will resume at 2:15 p.m.
12:35 p.m. Defense attorney Fernando Mack cross-examines Trina about Malissa's alleged threats against police and Trina says that Malissa made comments.

12:27 p.m. Trina testifies about Malissa's drug use and that she was gang-raped while living with a family down south. After that, she says Malissa left the shelter she had been living in and began living on the streets.
12:18 p.m. Prosecution calls a witness for a short bit of testimony before the court breaks for lunch.
She is identified as Trina Marie Williams, a first cousin of Malissa Williams, but Trina says "she was more like my sister...and we were born a few months apart...and we were very close."
12:01 p.m. Assistant County Prosecutor James Gutierrez has Saraya confirm that Cleveland police and BCI agents looked for the gun and never found one.
11:58 a.m. Saraya agrees that a total of 40 BCI agents investigated this incident and that none of them ever found a gun that was used by the suspects Timothy Russell and Malissa Williams.
11:50 a.m. Judge goes back on the record as the prosecution re-directs questions to BCI agent John Saraya.
11:42 a.m. Judge takes a 5-minute break, will have Saraya back on the stand, and after re-direct questioning by prosecutors, will break for lunch.
11:23 a.m. D'Angelo contains to walk Saraya through Brelo's statements to him during his interview regarding what happened after he first heard shots fired and his demeanor at the time.

11:07 a.m. Saraya testifies that Brelo told him that he heard shots fired as he pulled his cruiser onto what he called the "dirt road" at Heritage Middle School and was putting his cruiser into the park position.

11:03 a.m. D'Angelo questions Saraya about the statements the officers made during the chase over the police radio. He asks Saraya about what Officer Michael Brelo said about what he heard over the radio.
10:25 a.m. Judge reconvenes the trial with D'Angelo still cross-examining Saray.
10:09 a.m. Judge takes a break until 10:25 a.m.
10:06 a.m. Saraya is being asked about where shell casings were found and more information about the grassy area by the Heritage Middle School parking lot.
9:52 a.m. D'Angelo asks Saraya about the officers who were crying or had tears in their eyes when he interviewed them right after the incident inside Heritage Middle School.
He's asking about the general demeanor of all of the officers.
9:26 a.m. D'Angelo asks Saraya about how Malibu driver Timothy Russell tried to evade police by driving into the Happy's Pizza parking lot.
D'Angelo says that, despite all the police cars following with lights and sirens, there were no accidents with any civilian cars during the 22-minute chase.

9:10 a.m. Lead defense attorney Pat D'Angelo continued his cross-examination of BCI agent John Saraya, who is now with the crimes-against-children unit but was in the crime scene investigation unit back in 2012 when the pursuit occurred.
RECAP | Michael Brelo trial
SPECIAL SECTION | Cleveland Police Chase stories
SUMMARY

Assistant Cuyahoga County Prosecutors Rick Bell, Erica Barnhill, Sherrie Royster, James Gutierrez, and Sarah Denney, along with Cuyahoga County Prosecutor Tim McGinty, are representing the prosecution.

Defense attorneys Pat D'Angelo, Fernando Mack, Marissa Serrat and Thomas Shaughnessy are representing Brelo. O'Donnell is hearing the case himself and, therefore, there is no jury. The trial got underway on April 6.

It happened on Nov. 29, 2012. It's been about two years and five months since 59 Cleveland police cars wildly chased a car carrying two unarmed suspects across town, surrounding them in East Cleveland.
The events ended in a barrage of 137 shots fired by 13 officers. But only one -- Patrolman Michael Brelo -- will stand trial for the deaths of Timothy Russell, 43, and Malissa Williams, 30.
Brelo fired 49 shots, the most of any officer. He jumped on the victims' car hood and fired the last 15 shots after other officers had stopped shooting.
Brelo, 31, is charged with two counts of voluntary manslaughter.

Five other officers -- Sergeant Randolph Daley, Sergeant Patricia Coleman, Sergeant Paul Wilson, Lieutenant Jason Edens and Sergeant Michael Donegan -- are charged with dereliction of duty and will go to trial in the future.
The case involves many of the issues raised in a scathing report from the Department of Justice on the Cleveland Police Department's use of force and lack of accountability.
CLEVELAND -- A teenage boy was arrested with a fake gun in a Cleveland park Tuesday.
According to Cleveland police union president Steve Loomis, a 911 call was placed for three males flashing a gun at Mercedes Cotner Park, located at West 98th Street and Maywood Avenue.
One of them, a 15-year-old boy, had a BB gun with the orange tip removed, giving it the appearance of a real firearm.
"As we approached the juvenile, we ordered him to the ground," the police report states.
When asked about having a gun, the teen told reportedly told officers it was a BB gun he found on the roof of a building. He told them it was inside his jacket pocket.
Loomis told Channel 3 the 15-year-old was taken into custody and taken home to his parents. The boy will be charged with facsimile of a firearm.
In March 2014, a 19-year-old was shot while playing basketball at Mercedes Cotner Park.

Following The Ohio State University's victory over the University of Oregon football team in the first ever College Football Playoff National Championship on Monday, U.S. Sens. Rob Portman (R-OH), Sherrod Brown (D-OH), Ron Wyden (D-OR), and Jeff Merkley (D-OR) on Tuesday settled a friendly wager with an O-H-I-O photo on the Capitol Steps.
Last week the senators agreed that if The Ohio State University was victorious, Wyden and Merkley would join Portman and Brown in spelling out "O-H-I-O."
If the University of Oregon had won, Portman and Brown were to have learned how to "throw the O" alongside the Oregon Duck. All parties pledged to fulfill the bet in public on the Capitol Steps.
Glad Ohio State won?
CLEVELAND, Ohio -- On a sunny but cold Monday, federal prosecutors and defense attorneys gathered in U.S. District Court Judge Dan Polster's courtroom.
Just after 3:30 p.m., Polster re-sentenced Amish cult leader Samuel Mullet Sr. to 129 months in prison, down from the original sentence of 180 months.

He re-sentenced Amish cult members Johnny Mullet to 60 months; Lester Mullet to 60 months; Levi Miller to 60 months; Eli Miller to 60 months; Lester Miller to 43 months; Emanuel Schrock to 43 months; and Daniel Miller to 43 months.
The remaining eight members -- all women -- were re-sentenced to time already served.
Polster is to re-sentence 16 of the convicted defendants from 2012 after an appeals court overturned their sentencing back in August 2014.
RELATED | Amish Bergholz 'cult' leader, 15 more back in federal court
Outside the courthouse, at least one man was there to support the Amish.
A picture outside a courthouse about 114 miles from where the 16 were found guilty of beard- and hair-cutting attacks may speak volumes.
But during the 2012 trials, it was a different set of pictures that federal prosecutors used to show what happened down in several counties.
All of the defendants, including Bergholz 'cult' leader Samuel Mullet Sr., pleaded not guilty to charges that they forcibly cut the beards and hair of Amish men and women.
The five cutting attacks on a total of nine victims took place between September and November 2011 -- Sept. 6, Sept. 24, two on Oct. 4 and one of Nov. 9.
During the trials, prosecutors used pictures of horse mane shears allegedly used in the multiple attacks against other Amish.
Other exhibits included a camera allegedly used to photograph the victims' appearances, hair from the victims and transcripts of jailhouse calls by some of the defendants.
WKYC's Dick Russ was the first reporter to track down Mullet in Bergholz in October, 2011, only days after the second and third of the attacks had taken place.
WKYC was the only TV station that managed to interview Samuel Mullet Sr. Russ interviewed Mullet Sr. as Mullet Sr. sat atop a bulldozer on his 880-acre farm in Bergholz.
WATCH WKYC interview
At the time of Russ' interview, Mullet Sr. had not been charged with a crime.

In the Oct. 9, 2011 interview, the leader of a break-away Amish sect denied he had anything to do with a series of beard-cutting attacks which took place in several counties in eastern Ohio in September and October 2011.
One more attack occurred later in November.
Mullet Sr. did admit that he knew about the raids, in which Amish men have their beards cut off, and Amish women and men have had their hair cut, but had nothing to do with the incidents.
Additional exhibits included letters from one of 16 defendants and video and audio recordings of interviews with other defendants
Prosecutors even used some video footage taken by WKYC when Samuel Mullet Sr. was interviewed.
WATCH | Prosecutors use WKYC-TV footage during Amish trial
The trial centered on leader Samuel Mullet Sr., then-66, who was found guilty of planning the attacks in October-November 2011 in several Ohio counties in a dispute over religious differences.
PHOTOS | Amish beard-cutting trial

Besides conspiracy, the jury convicted Mullet Sr. on six additional charges, including lying to the FBI on Nov. 22, 2011, when asked about the attacks. Jurors acquitted him on two other counts, destroying a bag of hair brought back from one of the attacks and the Sept. 24, 2011, attack on David Wengard.
In fact, Count 3, the attack on Wengard, saw none of the other three defendants charged in that count guilty.
WATCH VIDEO | Prosecution: Amish verdict a triumph for freedom of religion

Defense attorneys had conceded the hair cuttings took place but argued that the government was overreaching by calling what happened hate crimes. They argued the cuttings were merely personal family disputes, so-called "family feuds."
The original sentencings took place in January 2013.
CLEVELAND -- The Cleveland Indians are mourning the loss of Hall of Famer Al Rosen.
Al "Flip" Rosen, 91, played his entire 10-year Major League career in an Indians uniform (1947-1956). He was a 4-time A.L. All-Star and drove in 100 runs five straight seasons.

"We lost a cherished member of the Indians family last night. Watching Al play was a true joy and something Indians fans of our generation still cherish," said Larry Dolan, father of Indians owner Paul Dolan.
Rosen was named Executive of the Year in 1987 as President and General Manager of the San Francisco Giants.
"He was an inspiration to us all and had a special presence, strength and intellect. His fierce competitive nature and toughness was legendary," said Indians President Mark Shapiro.
Edward Hickson is drowning in a flood of dead young black men. Yet the funeral director refuses to allow the bullet-riddled bodies to pull him under.
Hickson understands the Dunbar community of Fort Myers needs him. He is their grief bearer and calming presence; he restores dignity to those who lost it along the way.

And, though Hickson is willing and strong enough to shoulder Dunbar's death pains, he prays the bloody water recedes. Yes, Dunbar's senseless killings help Hickson provide for his family, but he would rather lose business than treasured lives.
However, Hickson's prayers have gone unanswered. Violent black-on-black crime continues throughout Fort Myers. So, he continues to do what he learned from his father 35 years ago in Arcadia.
AN UNDERTAKER'S ORIGIN

Hickson's father, a second-generation funeral director, taught Hickson how to care for the living and dead when he was 12 years old. "Back then, there were no EMTs. So my father and I rushed to the scene, secured the person as best we could, then rushed them to the ER," Hickson, now 48, remembers.

Most deaths that Hickson and his father encountered resulted from natural causes or car accidents. Murders were rare, but there was one that Hickson hasn't forgotten. A high school classmate's throat was cut in a bar fight. "That was tough to deal with. We were good friends and played baseball together," Hickson says.
Life soon returned to normal in the quiet rural town. Hickson continued working with his father, did well in high school and fished often. However, a phone call from Dunbar shattered the silence.
CALL FOR HELP

In the 1980s, the cocaine epidemic was laying waste to the predominately black Dunbar community. There were so many drug-related killings that Finley Carter, Dunbar's prominent funeral director, needed help. He called Hickson's father. "We would drive down on weekends to help out. And, after I graduated high school and got my mortuary license, I came down by myself." Hickson remembers.
By 1995, Hickson's experience and technical skill gave him confidence to open his own funeral home on Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard in Dunbar.

It was during this time that Hickson developed his own way of caring for the living and dead. Listening to and discerning the needs of grieving families, guiding them through the intricate process of laying one to rest, providing financial assistance, and talking candidly with young people about their plight are ways in which he connects.

In the early 2000s, there was a slight downtick in killings in Fort Myers. It seemed that the worst was over. It wasn't. In the past five years, violent crime, especially in Dunbar, has neared all time highs.

A young man recently told Hickson that living in Dunbar is like being in war. "Many of the killings taking place, he said, were like casualties of war," Hickson said. "There seems to be zero understanding on the streets."
ON HIS WAY

Hickson and his wife Priscilla watch the local news with angst. More often than not, a killing in Dunbar is the top story and minutes later Hickson's phone rings. Yes. He saw the news. Yes. He is on his way.
One such call came last October. Andrew Faust Jr., 5, was killed in a drive by shooting in Dunbar. "All I saw was a baby," Hickson said of seeing Andrew's lifeless body on a cold, metal gurney.
It took the master mortician hours to prepare Andrew. Most of that time, Hickson spent praying that the killings in Dunbar would end.
WASHINGTON -- RNC Chairman Rance Priebus announced that Jeff Larson will be the CEO for the 2016 National Convention in Cleveland. He also was recently appointed RNC survivor.
Priebus said, "Jeff's leadership over the last two election cycles has been critical four our success as a committee, and I'm personalgrateful that he will serve as convention CEO."
As Chief of Staff, Larson is credited with helping the RNC break fundraising records in 2011 and 2012 to wipe out a $25 million debt.

In a statement, Larson said. " I am honored to serve as the CEO of the Republican National Convention. From planning and preparation to execution and implementation, I will work to the best of my abilities to ensure the Republican Party holds a successful national convention to showcase not only our nominee but our party's vision of the future for this country."

Larson has a background as a businessman and political strategist. Earlier in his career, he was a campaign staffer for George H.W. Bush and an adviser on both of George W. Bush's presidential campaigns.
Follow WKYC's Tom Beres on Twitter @TomBeres
WASHINGTON — Congressional Republicans this week will take steps towards passing the first GOP budget in nearly 10 years.

The 10-year fiscal blueprint, which does not have the force of law, would balance the budget within a decade, while raising no taxes. Further, the Republican budget increases defense spending and, potentially, paves the way for a renewed effort to repeal President Obama's health care law.

"The balanced budget before us is premised on a simple truth that Washington has a spending problem, not a revenue problem," Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky, said Monday as the Senate began debate. "I know that this can be hard for some to acknowledge, but politicians have a duty to the American people to simply admit it."

While Democrats are largely cut out of the majority-driven budget process, they will have opportunities to have votes on their fiscal priorities in amendments offered on the floor. For instance, Senate Democrats plan to offer a number of amendments on proposals to eliminate tax breaks for the wealthy, to raise the minimum wage, and fund transportation projects, among others.

"The federal budget is about our national priorities and our values. It is about who we are as a nation and what we stand for," said Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., the ranking member of the Budget Committee. "The Republican budget has a set of priorities that are way, way, way out of touch with where the American people are."

Votes on the competing House and Senate GOP budgets will consume much of the week's legislative work, with both chambers expected to approve the measures before Congress adjourns Friday for a two-week recess. Senate Budget Committee Chairman Mike Enzi, R-Wyo., said they are working to enact a joint budget resolution by the statutory April 15 deadline.

If Republicans can agree to a joint budget resolution, which sets spending levels for the upcoming fiscal year, they could also trigger a protected legislative process known as reconciliation. Republicans intend to use that process to repeal Obamacare, because it requires only a majority vote and cannot be filibustered. Even if they are successful, however, Obama would veto the measure if it reaches his desk.

GOP leaders are hopeful that the appeal of targeting Obamacare will help ease ongoing intra-party divides over defense spending. Both the House and Senate budget will include additional funds for a war account meant to mitigate the effects of impending across-the-board cuts to defense and domestic programs.

However, some deficit hawks view the move as a budgetary gimmick that still contributes to the deficit. Other conservatives do not believe the budget balances quickly enough. A group of House conservatives in the Republican Study Committee released a budget Monday that achieves balance in six years and relies on deeper spending cuts.

The Senate budget is also more timid when it comes to Medicare. The House budget once again includes a call to overhaul the system from a guaranteed benefit to a premium support program where seniors are subsidized to buy private insurance. The Senate budget keeps Medicare intact, but calls for savings. Getting one chamber to embrace the other's approach will be a challenge in budget negotiations.

Failure to advance a joint resolution would be an embarrassing defeat for the nascent GOP majority. Republicans campaigned on their ability to pass a budget and the inability to do so would highlight the ongoing divides within the GOP's establishment and conservative wings.

House Democrats also unveiled Monday their competing budgetary vision. It largely mirrors Obama's budget request that calls for $1.8 trillion in new taxes over the next decade from the wealthy and corporations. It would keep Medicare, Social Security and Obamacare intact, but it would add to the projected 10-year deficit. The Democratic budget will get a vote, but it has no chance of passage. Rather, the competing budget allows the parties to draw a stark contrast on their competing policy agendas.
U.S. Sen. Chuck Grassley, who was ridiculed during the 2014 campaign as an Iowa farmer who didn't go to law school, became chairman Thursday of the U.S. Senate Judiciary Committee.

Senate Judiciary Committee Republicans voted Wednesday to elect the Iowa Republican as chairman. The results were then ratified Thursday during a meeting of the Republican conference. He becomes the first nonlawyer to head the judiciary panel.

One of the memorable moments of the last campaign occurred in March 2014 when a Republican opposition research firm, America Rising, posted a video online that showed then-U.S. Rep. Bruce Braley, D-Iowa, speaking to a group of lawyers at a fundraiser in Texas.

"If you help me win this race, you may have someone with your background, your experience, your voice — someone who's been literally fighting tort reform for 30 years in a visible and public way on the Senate Judiciary" Committee, said Braley, a trial lawyer who was seeking to succeed Democrat Tom Harkin in the U.S. Senate.

"Or you might have a farmer from Iowa who never went to law school, never practiced law, serving as the next chair of the Senate Judiciary. Because if Democrats lose the majority, Chuck Grassley will be the next chair of the Senate Judiciary."

Braley subsequently apologized to Grassley. But he never recovered from the negative fallout after his remarks became public, and he subsequently lost his U.S. Senate race to Republican Joni Ernst. Braley couldn't be immediately reached for comment Thursday.

Grassley, 81, who plans to seek re-election in 2016, made no mention of Braley's statement in assuming the chairmanship of the Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday. He said in a prepared statement that he looks forward to a productive Congress, and he appreciates the confidence of the members of the Judiciary Committee.

"The Judiciary Committee handles a broad policy jurisdiction and oversight portfolio, as well as the vetting of nominees for lifetime appointments to the federal judiciary. These are all important responsibilities that committee members take very seriously," Grassley said. "My goal is to promote transparency and accountability, restore the committee's role as a true check on the massive and powerful federal bureaucracy, and forward issues key to keeping America on the cutting edge of technology and business growth."

Grassley added: "We'll have an agenda that enhances the economy and protects consumers; reduces regulatory burdens on businesses and curbs abuses to our civil justice system; shields kids from drugs and child predators; protects taxpayer dollars from waste, fraud and abuse; focuses on securing the border and improves legal immigration opportunities; and adapts our criminal laws to rapidly advancing technology."
WASHINGTON – The backlog of maintenance work at Florida's national parks is approaching $195 million, according to a new report by the National Park Service.

Everglades National Park has the most deferred maintenance, with a $58.9 million price tag. It is followed by Dry Tortugas National Park ($56.9 million), Canaveral National Seashore ($22.2 million), Gulf Islands National Seashore ($20.9 million) and Big Cypress National Preserve ($20 million).

Nationwide, national parks face a $11.5 billion backlog — an increase of $190 million over last year's estimate. The park service counts as deferred maintenance repairs to roads and bridges, visitor centers, trails, and campgrounds that have been put off for more than a year.

In releasing the maintenance report, National Park Service Director Jonathan Jarvis pointed out President Barack Obama's fiscal 2016 budget proposes additional funding to reduce the backlog and spruce up the parks as part of efforts to mark the agency's 100th birthday.

"As we invite more Americans to discover the special places in the national park system during our centennial celebration, we need to have facilities that can accommodate them and provide the best possible visitor experience," Jarvis said.
Crumbling park roads and bridges account for about half the maintenance backlog. Florida is no exception:

•At Everglades National Park, which had more than 1.1 million visitors last year, most postponed work involves repairing paved and unpaved roads, NPS records show. Another $7.8 million is for building renovations.
•At Canaveral National Seashore on the Space Coast, which hosted more than 1.4 million visitors, deferred maintenance on roads accounted for almost all the park's backlog.
•At Gulf Islands National Seashore in Florida's Panhandle, visited by nearly 4.5 million in 2014, $16.4 million of the backlog is earmarked for roads.
Obama's budget calls for increasing parks spending by $433 million, to $3 billion. The park service estimates its staffing would increase by almost 500 full-time employees.
The budget includes $242.8 million to deal with the most urgent deferred maintenance.
Chilly reaction
But the proposal has received a chilly reaction from some Republicans in the GOP-controlled Congress.

Republican Rep. Tom McClintock of California, chairman of the House Natural Resources subcommittee that oversees the park system, said during a budget hearing last week record attendance at the parks is "an illusion" created by the huge numbers visiting the new World War II Memorial and the Franklin Roosevelt Memorial.

He said lodging is down by 330,000 annually, or about 10 percent, and RV and tent camping also have declined. He questioned why the park service would be looking to add new properties when it's having difficulty maintaining existing parks.

Craig Obey, senior vice president with the National Parks Conservation Association, told a different House subcommittee last week 73 percent of people polled in a recent survey said it's important the nation's parks are fully restored and ready for the centennial in 2016.

"This is a critical time for our national park system and the National Park Service, which celebrate their 100th birthday next year," Obey said. "Our parks, though beloved by Americans from all walks of life and celebrated worldwide, are under significant financial strain."

The new director of the resort and hospitality management program at Florida Gulf University views his mission as to elevate the program in prominence and earning power.

The program, in its 11th year, has graduated 598 students, and won regional recognition for educating the next generation of hospitality leaders for hotels and country clubs in Southwest Florida and beyond.

Randall Upchurch, who worked at hotels while earning degrees in a mix of non-hospitality majors, believes time is ripe to broaden program services, raise its profile — and in a variety of ways tap into more private-sector funding.
"One of my charges is to get the school of resort and hospitality management named," Upchurch said, noting:
"I will be out talking to the Harris Rosen types to see how we can take this program from promise to prominence."

In 2000, Orlando hotel magnet Harris Rosen donated $18 million and a 20-acre site to the University of Central Florida, to help build what would become the world-renowned Rosen College of Hospitality Management.
Donations on the scope of Rosen's are hard to come by, said Abraham Pizam, Rosen college dean.
Of about 145 collegiate hospitality programs, Pizam said, "only three or four have gotten significant donations like ours, in the tens of millions of dollars."
However, "the money doesn't necessarily have to come from one source," Pizam noted. A funding program could work with a number of philanthropists.

FGCU's hospitality program has benefit from several millions contributed by the Sugden family. The university's welcome center bears Margaret Sugden's name; her late husband, Herbert, is namesake for the building that holds classrooms and learning laboratories with facilities similar to those at a resort hotel, a spa and a country club.
Upchurch is building on the work of Sherie Brezina, associate FGCU professor and founding director of the resort and hospitality management program.
Brezina took early steps toward broadening the scope of hospitality studies by helping to attract the PGA Golf Management to FGCU in 2004.
To grow further in scope and in prominence, "we have to look beyond ... the state funding us for everything," Upchurch said. Among the possibilities:
• Certificate-earning training to help mid-level employees move up the ranks at hotels, country clubs and other centers of hospitality service.
• Market-rate, credit-earning programs. Market rate means tuition would be whatever the market would bear, presumably more than the amount an FGCU student and in-state resident would pay.
One market-rate effort could be joint-degree programs with non-U.S. universities, possibly one in China.
• Expansion of online programs for all kinds of students, in and out of FGCU.
Upchurch is positive the university is ready to take these big steps:
"What drives this state? Tourism. It's big, and it's alive and well right out our back door."
Connect with this reporter @Alvascribe (Twitter) and LauraPatrickRuane (Facebook).
FGCU's new director for resort and hospitality management
•Name: Randall "Randy" Upchurch
•Age: 57
•Born & reared: Cape Girardeau, Mo.
•First hotel job: Night auditor, Ramada Inn, Columbia, Mo., 1982
•Last hotel job: General manager, Drury Inns, St. Louis, Mo. 1990-92
•Degrees: All from University of Missouri-Columbia. Ph.D in practical arts and technical education; master's in counseling and personnel services; and bachelor's in psychology.

•University career highlights: Dean of academics, FIU Chaplin School of Hospitality & Tourism Management and editor of Hospitality Review; director, School of Hospitality Leadership, University of Wisconsin-Stout; faculty member with various leadership roles at University of Florida, Rosen College of Hospitality Management, Orlando; and assistant professor, Black Hills State University, College of Business and Public Affairs, Spearfish, S.D.
SPECIAL SERIES: Voices of the Everglades

President Barack Obama will visit the Florida Everglades on Wednesday, Earth Day, in his effort to call attention to climate change. The president in today's weekly address will talk about the effects of climate change and how they can't be ignored.
Details for Obama's visit have not been released.

The federal and state governments have spent millions of dollars to restore the Everglades. The network of low-lying lands and wetlands emerged from residing seas about 3,000 years ago in its latest incarnation — the region has been above and below water several times over the course of millions of years.
At least part of the system will be underwater again according to various sea level and climate change predictions.
Below is the president's weekly talk to the nation.
Hi everybody. Wednesday is Earth Day, a day to appreciate and protect this precious planet we call home. And today, there's no greater threat to our planet than climate change.

2014 was the planet's warmest year on record. Fourteen of the 15 hottest years on record have all fallen in the first 15 years of this century. This winter was cold in parts of our country – as some folks in Congress like to point out – but around the world, it was the warmest ever recorded.

And the fact that the climate is changing has very serious implications for the way we live now. Stronger storms. Deeper droughts. Longer wildfire seasons. The world's top climate scientists are warning us that a changing climate already affects the air our kids breathe. Last week, the Surgeon General and I spoke with public experts about how climate change is already affecting patients across the country. The Pentagon says that climate change poses immediate risks to our national security.

And on Earth Day, I'm going to visit the Florida Everglades to talk about the way that climate change threatens our economy. The Everglades is one of the most special places in our country. But it's also one of the most fragile. Rising sea levels are putting a national treasure – and an economic engine for the South Florida tourism industry – at risk.

So climate change can no longer be denied – or ignored. The world is looking to the United States – to us – to lead. And that's what we're doing. We're using more clean energy than ever before. America is number one in wind power, and every three weeks, we bring online as much solar power as we did in all of 2008. We're taking steps to waste less energy, with more fuel-efficient cars that save us money at the pump, and more energy-efficient buildings that save us money on our electricity bills.

So thanks in part to these actions, our carbon pollution has fallen by 10 percent since 2007, even as we've grown our economy and seen the longest streak of private-sector job growth on record. We've committed to doubling the pace at which we cut carbon pollution, and China has committed, for the first time, to limiting their emissions. And because the world's two largest economies came together, there's new hope that, with American leadership, this year, the world will finally reach an agreement to prevent the worst impacts of climate change before it's too late.

This is an issue that's bigger and longer-lasting than my presidency. It's about protecting our God-given natural wonders, and the good jobs that rely on them. It's about shielding our cities and our families from disaster and harm. It's about keeping our kids healthy and safe. This is the only planet we've got. And years from now, I want to be able to look our children and grandchildren in the eye and tell them that we did everything we could to protect it.
Thanks everybody, and have a great weekend.
Who would have thought a column about a fender bender could have so many layers?
Certainly not Judy and Arthur Evans who were rear-ended on Nov. 22 by a Cadillac limousine driven by Mark Sheerin, the owner of Maintain Domain Etc. Inc., an Estero-based home watch business.
In addition to offering residence checking, errand services and mail pick up for snowbirds and temporary residents, Maintain Domain has a limo service.

"As of now, we are operating out of the Fort Myers International Airport (sic) and servcing (sic) Southwest Florida. Notify us of your arrival or departure time, and we will be there," the website for the company states.

The interesting thing about that is I can't find where Sheerin and Maintain Domain are licensed to run a limo service. The company doesn't have vehicle for hire permits required by Lee County and the Lee County Port Authority. Those permits ensure the company has safe vehicles, drivers who have good records, and insurance.
So keep that information in mind while you read what happened after Sheerin's Cadillac plowed into the Evanses.

The couple's Lexus was relatively unscathed. "(It) must be well-built because all we got was a little buckling on the bumper and scratches," Arthur Evans said. "He seemed like a very nice chap. He said, 'I'm awfully sorry. There's not a lot of damage. I'll take care of it.'"
And with an exchange of cards and phone numbers, the couple, Sanibel Island snowbirds, continued on to the airport to pick up Mr. Evans' recently widowed sister-in-law who was flying in from England.

On the way home from the airport the Evanses noticed a firetruck near where their accident had been. Judy Evans asked if it was possible they had leaked oil and the firetruck was cleaning it up. But Arthur concluded the Lexus was fine, save for the bumper.
According to the report from the San Carlos Park Fire District, the firetruck was responding to a call about a black 1994 Cadillac limousine, "with the engine compartment fully involved in fire."
The operator/owner was listed as "Mark Sherrin" (sic) and the business name "Maintain Domain, Inc."

Over the course of the next few weeks the Evanses corresponded with Sheerin about their car. He wanted them to take it to a place in Fort Myers but when he couldn't get in touch with anyone there, he sent this text message: "I won't hold you up any longer go ahead and have it painted were (sic) you wish. Sorry for the delay Mark."
The repair bill was $769.91, which included a rental car for a two days.

Sheerin told the Evanses he mailed them a check for the total, but it must have been lost. Then he said his wife mailed another. It too, never arrived. Then Sheerin said he would meet Arthur Evans in Fort Myers and give them a check. He never showed up.
And he avoided me. He didn't return my calls or answer my email.

Admittedly, Sheerin has had a run of bad luck. A post on his business Facebook page, made a few days before he ran into the Evanses, show several photographs of a Lincoln Town Car with serious front-end damage under the post: "OUCH that hurt ;-((" and "I lost my baby ;-))"

And the luck for Sheerin and Maintain Domain Etc. may get worse. Authorities now know he's running a jitney service, his insurance company has found out about the second wreck causing the engine fire, and any of his customers who are reading this article will learn that he doesn't keep his word.

According to the Book of Exodus, for 40 years Moses and the Jews wandered in the desert seeking the Promised Land. Republicans in the Kentucky House of Representatives know exactly what that's like. In fact, they've been wandering in the political desert for over twice as long as Moses, 95 years, or since 1920 when they held a 55-45 advantage among that chamber's 100 seats.

You can forgive the GOP House members for looking a little shell-shocked last week as the 2015 session of the General Assembly convened in Frankfort. Instead of organizing the House as the majority party, a widely predicted outcome of last fall's elections, the Republican caucus is still the minority caucus with only 46 members, the same number it held going into the 2014 campaign. Their own Promised Land still eludes them.
RELATED | A young family's guide to the 2015 General Assembly

Because of the vast estrangement between the American people and President Barack Obama, 2014 may have been the greatest year at the polls for the Republican Party since, well, perhaps since its founding in 1854.

Nationally, Democrats now hold fewer state legislative seats than they have in 87 years (1928). Democrats have majorities in both legislative chambers in just 11 states, the fewest in 150 years. The GOP controls 69 of the country's 99 state legislative chambers (Nebraska only has a Senate). Republicans won majorities in such ice-blue states as Maine (20-15, Senate), Minnesota (72-62, House), and Washington (25-24, Senate). Neighboring Tennessee, not too long ago affiliated with the Solid (Democratic) South, today has 6 Democratic senators left out of 33.
So what happened? How did such a tsunami fail to swamp Kentucky's House?
RELATED | Kentucky General Assembly's top lobbying spenders

Many Republican candidates, both among those who lost as well as a few that won, are still questioning the decision by the state Republican Party and the House leadership in early 2014 to hire a consulting firm out of Indianapolis called Mark It Red. Although only in existence since 2012, Mark It Red partner Mike Gentry nevertheless claims his firm is responsible for "flipping" Indiana's House over the last 12 years from a 47 member minority (out of 100 seats) to a super-majority of 71. Gentry's group had a trial run doing the consulting work for (now) Rep. Suzanne Miles, the Republican who won the sex scandal-plagued John Arnold's House seat in a December 2013 special election. With that rather thin resumé, Mark It Red was signed to create and implement a coordinated game plan with final responsibility for every contested House race in Kentucky, an effort in size and scale it had never undertaken anywhere outside of Indiana. Candidates, whether an incumbent or a challenger, were all but compelled to give Mark It Red carte blanche control over their campaigns. (Prominent contrarian Phil Moffett, running in Jefferson County's 32nd district, unsurprisingly opted out. He won anyway.)

Despite a promise to run individual races tailored to the unique issues of each district, Mark It Red, for the crucial stretch drive, crafted a one-size-fits-all, cookie-cutter campaign that looked the same in Paducah as it did in Owensboro as it did in Bullitt County as it did in Jessamine County — all losses, by the way, despite Mitch McConnell and other GOP local candidates in those areas winning, some in landslides. Those four races alone, against two vulnerable Democratic incumbents and in two open seats, could have made the difference in winning the House.

The coup de grace may have been Mark It Red's ill-advised decision to inject the volatile Right to Work issue into nearly every district where it was running the show. Reluctant candidates who questioned this approach were assured that internal polling (done by the same firm (objectivity, s'il vous plait?) showed "60 percent or better" support for this white-hot button issue. Au contraire! Instead, it angered many voters in indisputably conservative areas but who nonetheless regard a union membership (or that of a family member) as an indispensable part of their economic security.

In its defense, Mark It Red pleads too much money (the GOP was vastly outspent), too much unfavorable redistricting, too much Democratic Speaker of the House Greg Stumbo, the one-man consulting firm whose tactics and strategies were more than a match for the visiting Hoosiers engaged in regicide.

But all of those advantages (minus, of course, Mr. Stumbo) were also held by the Democrats in next-door West Virginia. Outspent $4.2 million to $2.3 million and competing in districts redrawn by Democrats and, notably, without any outside consultants, Republicans added 17 (!) seats to their 47-member House caucus, winning control of that 100-person chamber for the first time since 1931. According to GOP State Director Matt Dailer, scarcely any of his candidates in that blue collar state even mentioned the words "Right to Work."

As a consequence of Mark It Red's Procrustean determination to make their Indiana model fit Kentucky's far different political culture, the Republicans' ambitious plans for badly needed education reform, tax reform, personal service contract reform, Medicaid reform, and greater protection for pre-born life, among other conservative aspirations, will have to await another day and time. That will come in two short years with another election.

But will 2016 be as game-changing a year as 2014? Will a Republican governor, perhaps elected this fall, go nuclear for a GOP House majority in 2016 or will he cut a deal with Svengali Stumbo to forgo such an effort in exchange for a promise to advance that governor's legislative agenda (except for Right to Work) and budget priorities through the House? Until then, all that Republican House members can do is lick their somewhat self-inflicted wounds, bide their time, and ponder the most tantalizing words in politics: "What might have been."
In the shadow of the wire: The French words used in today's column are in honor of Stephane Charbonnier — vive la "Charlie Hebdo!" Vive la France! Vive la Democratie!
Bob Heleringer is a Louisville attorney and, from 1980 to 2002, served in Kentucky's House from the 33rd District. He can be reached at helringr@bellsouth.net.
The little girl with chubby cheeks stands with her two older sisters, clutching a flower in both hands.

Jennie Truncale was just 3 when someone showed up at her Connecticut home in 1909, eager to use a new box camera. Her sisters, clad in white dresses, were ready for the surprise photo op, but her parents took a few minutes to prep their energetic toddler, who was honing her hands-on skills.

"They gave her a flower to hold because her hands were dirty from playing in the sandbox," said her daughter, Carrie Blair, who hosted a 109th birthday party Saturday for her mother at their home in The Forest community.

Photos like that one tell Jennie's story — of a girl who started working in high school to help support her family, of a young woman who married the handsome man she waved to at the bus stop every morning, of a longtime factory worker who made bullets during World War II.
"We were average people," Truncale said as friends began filling the lanai while family attending from throughout the country prepared dinner and served drinks.
They weren't rich and they weren't famous. But her life, like any, is filled with fond memories and fascinating stories.
Journey to the states

Her mother, Louise Travisano, journeyed from Italy in 1904 with Jennie's two older sisters. She didn't speak English and planned to meet her husband, who had left early to get settled in the United States.
While they were crossing the Atlantic, he died. Friends who were here helped her settle in Waterbury, Conn. She married Michael Travisano and they had eight children, Jennie being their first.

The children helped pick fruit at Coe's farm, where their father was foreman. Jennie began working in high school and worked for three decades at Scovill Manufacturing Co., through the 1930s, '40s and '50s. That's where she made bullets during World War II.
"I worked hard," she said. "I was always busy."

Jennie met her husband, Charles "Leo" Truncale, after seeing him at the bus stop outside their home. She'd wave from a second-story window, and he asked her out. He also worked in a factory and worked for the city during the Depression.
Jennie has her honeymoon dress, a slender chiffon column in a dark, subtle print with a matching jacket and belt.

They worked hard but enjoyed their time off, driving to New York City once a month with friends to go to the Copacabana. He wore a suit and tie and fancy, shiny shoes; she'd pull her curly black hair back, don a long dress and top it with a fox jacket.

Carrie, their only child, was born when Jennie was 27. Carrie, 82, became a nurse and had four sons and became a grandmother. Jennie kept her cheerful, energetic demeanor. Leo died when she was 78, and mother and daughter have lived at The Forest for about 20 years.
"She's a great kidder. She loves to play jokes," her daughter said. "And she enjoyed going out."
Jennie started using a walker a year ago and wears two hearing aids. Ever cheerful, she blew kisses to friends as they arrived Saturday.
"Hello, sweetheart," said Joan Leanza, a fellow member of Church of the Resurrection of Our Lord in Fort Myers.
"Hello, my love," Jennie responded.

Jennie and Carrie attended 3:30 p.m. Mass on Saturday. The Rev. Msgr. Stephen E. McNamara gave her 109 roses, and a special message scrolled on the church's website — "Happy Birthday, Jennie Truncale! 109 Years Young! May God bless you!"
When she turned 100, someone asked Jennie her advice for a long life. She responded readily on Saturday.
"Don't drink, don't smoke and walk the straight line," she said.
An exclusive club

At 109, Jennie Truncale is part of a select demographic. According to the Census Bureau, there were 53,364 centenarians in the U.S. in 2010. Even more exclusive, however, are those who reach supercentenarian status, defined as 110 or older. This group included just 330 in the U.S. in 2010, according to the Census Bureau.
The Chinese New Year is Thursday and millions of people around the world will welcome the Year of the Goat — one of 12 Chinese zodiac symbols.
Here in Des Moines, the Chinese Association of Iowa will hold its annual New Year celebration and awards ceremony Saturday at Merrill Middle School, 5301 Grand Ave.
Swallow Yan has been a part of the group for more than a decade. The group aims to bridge the gap between China and Iowa cultural activities and enrichment programs.

"We want to build up a strong community for career, education, culture so that our association and community members can feel like home in Iowa," Yan said. He is currently the association's executive director.
Yan talked to The Des Moines Register about the group and its 12th annual New Year celebration.
Q: Why does the association host cultural events like the Chinese New Year celebration?
A: Iowa is welcoming of diversity, and people from different backgrounds are all important elements of Iowa. We feel the Chinese culture is one part of Iowa's culture.
We are proud that we can come here to the community, to the state and to the culture and economy.
Q: What kind of awards does the Chinese Association of Iowa give out during the New Year celebrations?

A: Our biggest award for this year is the person of the year award presented to Drake University President David Maxwell. He has done tremendous work for the last 17 years to make Drake a great university and also establish a strong China program for the university.

More Chinese students have come to Drake in the last 17 years than ever before. He has done tremendous work of bringing Chinese students not only here but also have them grow and build up their resumes and credentials and future career development.

Also, we selected the leadership in diversity awards. One honoree is Merrill Middle School teacher Gayle Canada. Merrill has done a tremendous job working with us for this year's event. She has been a longtime volunteer for our association.
Our association has 30 percent non-Chinese members. We also send students from Iowa to China, so that it's mutual, two-way.
Q: What do you hope for the future of the Chinese Association of Iowa?
A: Our goal is to build up the bridge between Iowa and China and also to provide resources to the local Iowa communities. We feel this association plays a lot of roles.
This association played a very important role to help the governor bring Chinese Vice President Xi Jinping to Iowa for the second time.
It has done a lot of work to bring the state of Iowa and China together. We are very confident we can do more in the next 25 years.
Swallow Yan
AGE: 52.

Tourist season delivers economic benefits to Southwest Florida along with a singular lament for area drivers: traffic congestion.
Getting anywhere fast during the busiest time of year for Southwest Florida, when about 2.5 million visitors and seasonal residents are projected to bolster the population, can be a challenge.

Just ask Brian Holly, managing director for the Holiday Inn Fort Myers Airport-Town Center. The hotel offers complimentary guest shuttle service to and from Southwest Florida International Airport, promising a vehicle every 20 minutes.
During non-seasonal months, May through November, Holly said a single van can make the 7.2-mile round trip within that time frame. Currently, however, it's taking about 25 minutes – one way.
"We've basically had to double the amount of runs we make," Holly said. "We've had to get an extra van on the road so that creates additional labor and mileage costs.
"But it's the nature of the beast. The good news is this is shaping up as a really good high season for tourism. There's certain things you don't mind dealing with because of that."

Kevin Hess, co-owner of Jimmy John's in Fort Myers on busy Cleveland Avenue, said he and his wife Shawn explored every road in and out of the store before its opening in December in order to find the most efficient delivery routes.
"It obviously gets stretched a bit during peak traffic," Hess said. "But we have a pretty small delivery area. It's really just knowing when to stay off of 41 and take Fowler south instead."
To the airport

Some of Lee County roadways that experience the largest seasonal traffic increase, with some running as high as 163 percent above their 2013 average annual figures, are thoroughfares leading to and from the airport – Terminal Road, Treeline Avenue and Alico Road.

While official 2014 annual traffic counts are not yet available for Lee and Collier counties, preliminary figures from the Lee Department of Transportation show increases in average annual traffic at an overwhelming majority of the county's permanent count stations.

Most of those stations are already experiencing traffic volume above their annual averages. For example, Daniels Parkway west of Metro Parkway, which saw a 15 percent increase in average daily traffic in 2014 (from 40,100 cars to 46,000), experienced an additional 11 percent rise in daily volume during a seven-day stretch in mid-December (50,857), the official start of 2015 winter tourist season.
Early reports are indicating this season's traffic could return to levels not seen since 2006, before the economic downturn led to double-digit declines in Southwest Florida's overall traffic count.

"Based on what's being reported by law enforcement, we're seeing increased seasonal traffic compared to last year and the year before," said Debbie Tower, spokeswoman for the Florida Department of Transportation.
Dealing with delays

Between them, Lee and Collier's traffic operations centers are connected to nearly 600 signalized intersections. This allows DOT employees to monitor roadways and try to alleviate congestion problems when possible.

"What we can do from here is manage our traffic signal controllers," said Anthony Khawaja, Collier's chief traffic operation engineer. "We can adjust green time accordingly to try and keep traffic moving as smoothly as possible."

Khawaja said once a problem is confirmed, the center typically responds within five minutes. However, during peak season at peak hours of the day on heavily traveled stretches of the county's major roads, the impact of these alleviating measures is lessened.
"When all the approaches are busy, it's very difficult to make adjustments," he said. "When traffic is backed up in all four directions, what we try to do is balance the delay."

Randy Cercie, deputy director of Lee DOT, said the county uses traffic responsive control systems on a handful of intersections at its busiest roads, including Daniels Parkway, College Parkway and Del Prado Boulevard. These systems automatically check traffic counts at determined time intervals and if a certain vehicle threshold is reached, can independently alter signal light patterns without being "told" to do so by the traffic operations center, allowing for a quicker response to congestion problems.

Next year, Cercie said, Lee will begin using adaptive signal systems on heavily traveled corridors. While their exact locations are not yet finalized, these systems would link together a series of traffic signals, allowing one that is experiencing congestion to independently control not just its own timing but timing of the signals both preceding and following it.

Such proactive measures will be necessary as Southwest Florida enters a likely period of increased traffic, thanks to projected growth in tourism and permanent residents. The University of Florida's Bureau of Economic and Business Research projects Lee County's population will grow at an annual rate of 2.5 percent through 2040.

"Really I think the next couple of years it will be higher than that when you get down to it," said Don Scott, executive director of the Lee County Metropolitan Planning Organization. "For the foreseeable future, with the way the growth is going, there'll be more traffic."
Donna Burleson had been looking for a place to move on Fort Myers Beach.

Burleson, who is the manager at Heidi's Island Bistro, said she checks the website Trulia every day. That's where she saw an "amazingly cheap" two–bedroom, two-bath condo for rent. The same place appeared on Zillow and Craigslist, she said.

The condo was available for $600 a month and she contacted the man who said he was the owner. Burleson was suspicious, and rightly so, but she thought she should get information just in case. The place was listed as being "pet friendly" and Burleson has a dog.

After she inquired, she received an email response signed by the Rev. Richard C. Rosen. He told her the "house" was still available and the utilities were included in the monthly rent. Here's his email, exactly as written:

"In case you see any sign board, they are the Realtor in charge of my house before I decided to take over by myself. I am no more working with them and don't bother to contact them because formerly i wanted to sell the house before me and my Lovely Family now decided to rent it out instead of selling it out.
Get back to me so i can forward you the rental application form i would want you to fill out and also do get back to me asap with your picture as well so let me know whom i am renting my house to.
Please kindly contact me back via email instead of calling me because i will be very very busy at work.
Regards REV Richard C Rosen"
Now if that doesn't let you know you're not dealing with a native English speaker, I don't know what does. And it confirmed Burleson's suspicion this was a scam, but she played along.
"The more I kept responding the more I thought, 'This is ridiculous,'" Burleson said. "You would be amazed at the audacity of this guy."
Rosen told Burleson that as soon as he got a cashier's check from her for the deposit and first month's rent, he'd send her the keys.
He had provided a phone number but when I called it a voicemail message came on for "Barb."

The real property owner — whose name is not Rev. Rosen or Barb — was a little easier to catch up with. He has rented the condo for a number of years and now has it for sale. He didn't put up a rental listing and if he did, it wouldn't be $600 a month. He's not using a real estate agent and this was the first time he listed a property on Zillow.
And that's where I think his listing got hijacked since the only other place it appeared was on the bulletin board in the condo building.
A couple of years ago, real estate agents and property managers were regularly finding their listings copied by scammers.
That practice has waned a bit if Kathy Hawley's experience is any indication. Hawley, who is a co-owner of Hawley Properties Inc., attributed the decline to keeping her listings off free websites.
I think the current scam wave is attributable to for-sale-by-owner properties being listed on the web. And I'm basing this theory on the properties Rosen targeted.
He hijacked at least eight "for sale by owner" properties from all over the country and listed them for rent on Trulia and other websites for $600 to $750 a month.
I hate to say, "Never rent over the Internet," because there are people who have had success with the method. But I will say you need to be very, very careful.

And if you don't feel you can ferret out the scammers, call a real estate company and let them find a place for you. There are companies that specialize in rentals and have property management divisions that will gladly help you.
The landlord pays for this service so it costs you nothing. It may even save you money. And for sure, it will save you a lot of grief.
Melanie Payne is "@tellmel" on Twitter. Email TellMel@news-press.com or write to 2442 Martin Luther King Jr. Blvd.,Fort Myers, 33901, or phone 239-344-4772.
MELBOURNE, Fla. — The domed roof of the Air Force telescopic tracking station that stood for decades off a highway near Melbourne Beach has finally found a permanent home.
On Sunday, volunteers will move the disassembled dome via flatbed trailer to Wings of Dreams Aviation Museum at Keystone Heights Airport, about 10 miles southeast of Starke, Fla.
Museum officials plan to resurrect the donated dome as an astronomical observatory.

"This was very interesting to us. We are NASA artifact recipients, and this is space history. It's a historic space artifact, with a different type of story," said Susan King, museum managing director.
"We've saved other space artifacts that were destined for the scrap pile. Our goal is to erect the dome on-site within the calendar year. We're very excited. It's something we'll cherish," she said.
The Melbourne Beach tracking station was managed by the 45th Space Wing at Patrick Air Force Base as part of the Eastern Range communications network.
Inside the dome, a telescope with a 24-inch aperture monitored rocket launches in tandem with optical systems at Patrick, Cocoa Beach and Cape Canaveral Air Force Station.
Workers demolished the aging tracking station in 2008. The 1,100-pound dome was saved from destruction by Bob Nolan, a retired Air Force captain who spearheaded a dome-preservation campaign.

The North Brevard Historical Society assumed ownership in 2010 and transported the dome to Titusville, but Nolan brought the pieces back to the Melbourne Beach Old Town Hall History Center two years later.

In December, the Melbourne Beach Town Commission voted to discontinue a project to reassemble the dome there, and Nolan faced a Jan. 31 deadline to move the contraption elsewhere. The dome was moved into storage, facing a murky future.

King said museum officials learned of Nolan's plight via Florida Today news coverage. Their facility conducts an after-school astronomy program and hosts "star parties" under the direction of Francisco Reyes, an associate scientist with the University of Florida department of astronomy.
The dome will house large telescopes for these programs, she said. Museum officials have offered to name this completed facility the Nolan Observatory.

"We're very, very pleased that we have this opportunity to have that dome displayed," Nolan said. "Fifty years from now, kids will be able to understand the things that happened at NASA and the rockets that went up.
"My goal was to expose this to future generations in the United States," he said.
Wings of Dreams Aviation Museum has also taken possession of the space shuttle external fuel tank that had been displayed at the Kennedy Space Center Visitor Complex.
Neale also reports for Florida Today
CLEVELAND, Ohio -- Clean water is perhaps Northeast Ohio's most important and most underappreciated resource.

Led by Mayor Frank Jackson and the city of Cleveland, a host of groups are launching a year of public events to inform the public about the importance and value of Lake Erie and other water resources to our economy, recreation and environment.
"The Year of Clean Water" is a campaign led by the city's Office of Sustainability with the city's Water Department, Metroparks, the Northeast Ohio Sewer District and the Cleveland Water Alliance.
Those visiting workshops and events will be eligible to win prizes including a two-night getaway package at Cuyahoga Valley National Park.
For more information visit clevelandwateralliance.org/tour.
The first event is Friday, Jan. 23, at 11 a.m. at City Hall. It's billed as a program to learn about local innovations, resources and groups working to keep our water clean.
WASHINGTON — Republicans have a wide-open presidential race. Democrats are jealous.

As presidential contenders begin to officially announce their campaigns, a nationwide USA TODAY/Suffolk University Poll finds no pining for Mitt Romney among Republicans and no consensus behind anybody else.

And while there seems to be no real contest on the other side, an overwhelming majority of Democrats wish there was. A 55% majority of Democrats say it's "very important" to them to see strong challenges to Hillary Clinton for the presidential nomination. Another 25% call it "somewhat important."

At the moment, though, no one seems poised to do that. Clinton, who launched her campaign on Sunday via video, was volunteered as the preferred nominee by 43% of Democrats. Five percent named Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren, who has said she's not running. Among the 413 Democrats surveyed, just two named former Maryland governor Martin O'Malley, who has said he is considering a bid. A single person named Vice President Biden.
About half of the Democrats surveyed, 48%, say they're undecided.
Among Republicans, there is no front-runner and no shortage of possibilities.

No GOP candidate scored as high as double digits, a sign of the most wide-open nomination contest in modern times. Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker was a narrow leader at 9%, followed by former Florida governor Jeb Bush at 8%, Texas Sen. Ted Cruz at 7% and Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul at 5%.

In response to the open-ended question, no one named Mitt Romney, the party's 2012 presidential nominee. He led the field at 16% in the USA TODAY/Suffolk Poll in January, but he has since said he doesn't plan to run in 2016.
Over the past three weeks, Cruz, Paul and Rubio formally have announced their campaigns with speeches before sizable audiences.

The poll of 1,000 people, taken Wednesday through Monday by landline and cellphone, has a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points. The samples of 413 Democrats and 369 Republicans have error margins of +/- 5 points.

There was a red flag in the findings for Jeb Bush, who is expected to command the most money and establishment support of any of his competitors. Asked whether there was a possible candidate they would consider unacceptable as the nominee, 11% of Republicans volunteered Bush's name — the most of any candidate.
Seven percent cited Paul, 5% Cruz, 4% New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie and 3% Walker.

Meanwhile, assessing the president who is already in the Oval Office, 48% of all those surveyed disapprove of the job Obama is doing; 42% approve. Those may be mediocre ratings, but they're better than those for Congress: 77% disapprove, 11% approve.
Just 25% say the country is headed in the right direction, a significant drop from the 36% who felt that way in January.
Follow @SusanPage on Twitter.
TRIPOLI, Libya (AP) — Gunmen stormed a luxury hotel in Libya's capital Tuesday, killing at least five foreigners and three guards, authorities said.
The attack, which including a car bombing, struck the Corinthia Hotel, which sits along the Mediterranean Sea.

Mahmoud Hamza, commander of the so-called Special Deterrent Force, told private satellite television station al-Nabaa that the situation was "under control" Tuesday afternoon, though he couldn't confirm the whereabouts of the gunmen. He also said five foreigners were killed, without elaborating.

Another security official earlier said the gunmen killed three guards and took hostages, but had no further information on who the captives were. He also said that two commercial landmark towers behind the hotel were evacuated out of security concerns. He spoke on condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to speak to reporters.

A hotel staffer said five masked attackers wearing bulletproof vests stormed the hotel after security at the gates tried to stop them. He said they entered the hotel and fired randomly at the staff in the lobby.

The staffer said the gunmen fired in his direction when he opened his door to look out. He said he joined the rest of the staff and foreign guests fleeing out the hotel's back doors into the parking lot.

When they got there, he said a car bomb exploded in the parking lot, only a hundred meters (yards) away. He said this came after a protection force entered the lobby and opened fire on the attackers. He said two guards were immediately killed. The staffer spoke on condition of anonymity because he feared retribution. He said the car bomb left at least five cars in the parking lot burned and damaged some windows in the hotel's facade.

He said the hotel had Italian, British and Turkish guests, but the hotel was largely empty at the time of the attack. He said the militia-backed Prime Minister Omar al-Hassi usually resides at the hotel, but was not there Tuesday. Al-Hassi's security guards also weren't there, he said. The hotel previously came under attack in 2013 when a former prime minister was abducted there.

Since the ouster and 2011 killing of Libyan dictator Moammar Gadhafi, the country has been torn among competing militias and tribes vying for power. Libya's post-Gadhafi transition has collapsed, with two rival governments and parliaments — each backed by different militias — ruling in the country's eastern and western regions. Tripoli has been hit with series of car bombs and shootings amid the turmoil.
The Malta-owned hotel is also where the United Nations support mission in Libya holds its meetings. The mission is currently hosting political talks with rival Libyan groups in Geneva.

Construction hats and strong opinions filled the room Tuesday when Lee County commissioners mulled impact fees.
But the conversation, while over two hours long, is nowhere near over.

After hearing from dozens of residents representing the construction industry, the Lee County School District, affordable housing experts and impact fee advocates, commissioners voted to set a public hearing to finally determine the fees' fate for the next three years.
At that March 3 meeting, commissioners will base their conversation on a 45 percent impact fee rate, or about $5,840 per home.
That number, which passed 4-1 in a motion by Commissioner Larry Kiker to set the hearing, is a good starting point for the conversation, Commissioner Cecil Pendergrass said.

But others have very different opinions of what the number should be, from Brian Hamman – who would like to see the 20 percent rate continued — to Frank Mann — who has consistently voted to keep the fees at 100 percent.

Last week, county staff recommended setting the fee for a single-family home at 85 percent, or about $11,116. That's more than triple the $2,942 builders pay for a single-family home, under the 80 percent reduction commissioners set in March 2013. They also recommended fee increases to multifamily homes and mobile home parks.
That reduction is set to expire March 13.
The fees are used for new construction of infrastructure and are collected only on new construction. Each city sets its own, independent of the county.

The board's chambers in the Old Lee County Courthouse filled early Tuesday with dozens of members of the construction industry, many wearing yellow plastic construction hats and buttons stating "Housing = Jobs."

Their opinions — that raising impact fees would negatively impact an industry that is still struggling to return from a recession, and that increased fees would be passed onto buyers of new homes — were reiterated by around a dozen speakers.

"Potentially, fewer projects will get started and the recovery loses some or all of its steam," said Russell Smith, division president for construction firm Lennar Homes. "Even though things are arguably improving ... we're still in the position where we have to be careful."
But dozens more public commenters supported returning fees to 100 percent, or close to that.

If impact fees returned to 100 percent, the school district would receive around $3.7 million in the first year and would have enough to pay the first year of a mortgage, about $3.6 million, on a new high school in the southern part of the county, Lee County School Board member Cathleen Morgan said in public comment.
The school district was against the initial reduction and thinks millions of dollars that could have been used to build new schools was lost during the two years since the fee has been lower.
Under the county's recommendations, which were based on an $88,000 study by a contractor, the percentage of impact fees going to roads would decrease but those to the school district would increase.
After the meeting, Morgan said she was "disappointed in the way the conversation went."
"The fact of the matter is, if the state isn't going to support our need to build, and the county isn't going to support it, we have no choice but to go to the taxpayers and ask them," she said.
At its Jan. 27 meeting, the school board voted to direct its staff to begin working on a ballot measure asking voters to approve a half-cent sales tax.
School officials say the district needs around $120 million to build three schools in the next few years, and that the tax could generate $45million-$50 million per year.
Several speakers at Tuesday's meeting addressed the possibility of a school-supported tax increase, and said they don't believe residents will vote for it.

Also against an increase were members of citizens' group Lee Public Voice, who've consistently said the county has lost millions in needed money for new infrastructure; advocates for affordable housing, who worried increased fees would mean lower-income residents couldn't afford new homes; and some environmental advocates, who said increasing the fees means less fighting for funds for other projects, including conservation.
What the commissioners think
Lee County's commissioners have widely varying ideas of what rate impact fees for new single-family homes should be set at. Here, their thoughts:

John Manning, District 1: Manning refrained from outlining his thoughts in Tuesday's meeting, stating March 3 would be the day for that. But after the meeting, he said he would have supported the 85 percent recommendation made by Lee County staff, or about $11,037.
•Cecil Pendergrass, District 1: Pendergrass quickly supported Larry Kiker's motion to start the conversation at 45 percent, and called that number a "good starting point."
•Larry Kiker, District 3: Made a successful motion to set a March 3 public hearing to discuss a 45 percent impact fee rate, or about $5,840.
•Brian Hamman, District 4: Has consistently said he'd like to keep impact fees at 20 percent, or about $2597.
•Frank Mann, District 5: Wants fees to return to 100 percent, or $12,985. He was the sole vote against lowering them in the first place in March 2013.
