It's said love covers a multitude of sins.

Beginning Monday in Miami-Dade County, and this morning across the state of Florida, gay and lesbian couples are applying for marriage licenses. Some see this as an expression of love. Others view this as just another sin. Same-sex marriage continues to divide religions and households.
Yet experts say the shift in perception across religious lines began more than a decade ago.

"It's happened faster than anyone thought it would happen," said Whitney Bauman, an associate professor in religious studies at Florida International University. "Sexual liberation has been quite contested and caused another great divide, not between religions, but within religions."
Rabbi Yossi Labkowski of Chabad of Cape Coral said while respecting differing ideas one has to stand up for one's principles.

"In the Bible, it is stated that marriage is between a man and woman," Labkowski wrote in an email. "In Judaism, marriage is a seen as Holy Union. This is verbalized under the Chupah-marriage ceremony canopy with the words, "you are sanctified to me." Sanctity can only be achieved if it is in line with G-d's will."
In contrast, Rabbi Jeremy Barras of Temple Beth El in Fort Myers holds a more liberal view. He is a strong advocate for gay rights and will preside over same-sex weddings.

"There is a shift in society. But, just because there is a shift doesn't mean we change what we know to be true," said Pastor Jamin Stinziano, elder and pastor at Summit Church in Estero, who disagreed with the court ruling. "It's wanting to honor the Lord and glorify him with the lives we live. His word is clear on what is right and wrong."
The Diocese of Venice holds to a statement by the Florida Conference of Catholic Bishops, which expressed disappointment in the "redefinition of marriage in Florida."

"The conjugal nature of a marriage between a man and a woman," the statement reads, "has provided for millennia the basis for norms of marital exclusivity and permanence that made possible stable families necessary for human flourishing."
Islam doesn't condone this type of sexual relationship, said Imam Abdul Hamid Samra, director of religious services at the Islamic Center of Greater Miami.

"We look at this action and we think those people they need our help and our support," Samra said. "I'm to be kind and respect them but make clear that this action is not accepted from a religious point of view."
Complex issue
"I knew two things when I was 4 years old," Ericson Proper, 47, of Naples said. "That I was gay and that I was going to be a priest."

But Proper said his world fell apart after he was asked to leave seminary because he is gay. Now a Buddhist for over 20 years and director of the Padmasambhava Buddhist Center-Naples, he said a Roman Catholic monk told him this was God shattering his boxes.
"The church won't have you," Proper said he was told. "So work out your salvation in your own way. ... The last words he told me were, 'go and dig until you find living water.'"

Buddhism, he said, changes according to the culture. It's main concern is whether a relationship is loving. Proper is planning to get married within the next year. The wedding is not in the classical Christian sense. Rather it will be a ritual where the community comes together and blesses the couple's intentions.

"Just the fact that the love I share could be recognized," Proper said. "That it has the same meaning as everyone else around me ... two beings that really want to support and nourish each other through good and bad."

To some in the same-sex community, their attraction is something to be changed, if possible. Ethan Martin is president of Revelation Ministry 1211, a local organization committed to helping people deal with unwanted same-sex attraction. Martin said he struggled with this for years, but has found peace. He is now a counselor for people with similar challenges.

"The goal is not heterosexuality, it's holiness," said Martin of Fort Myers. "It definitely becomes more difficult as society and the media is normalizing it. … My goal is to always point people to Jesus Christ. The message I would say is 'I love you, I'm not here to condemn you. ... Jesus spoke a message of go and sin no more.'"
The feelings of at least one religious leader reflects the complexity of gay marriage.

"We should not encourage," said Jinit Bhatt, priest at the Hindu Temple of Southwest Florida. "But if people are that way by nature, there is no way to change them. It's very harmful. Krishna said go with that flow ... no matter what you believe, if you're a good human being you will reach God."
Leo Stack tugs on his sunglasses, making sure to hide his eyes and the emotion that's about to pour out of him.

Stack is homeless. He's been homeless for 25 years. A 56-year-old veteran who once owned a business and home is living on the Fort Myers streets, unsure of where his next meal will come from. There are times when Stack struggles to make it through the day, especially when it comes to thinking about his three children whom he hasn't seen in years because of an ugly divorce.
"You see just how important it is to have fathers in connection with their children," said Stack, tapping his chest. "It's a necessity for social health."

Stack was one of about 1,000 homeless or impoverished Fort Myers residents who attended the 15th annual Lee County Homeless Service Day on Saturday at City of Palms Park. Myriad agencies and volunteers handed out blankets, shoes, pants, shirts, flu shots, haircuts, bus passes and other supplies. Counselors also discussed employment assistance and Veterans Affairs benefits with the homeless.

Lee County Homeless Coalition puts together the event to unite all resources. This week, the coalition is conducting its annual Lee County homeless count. In years past, the count would be conducted in one day. This year, the Coalition is surveying the population over a full week because it joined the federal government's Zero: 2016 campaign to end veteran homelessness. Last year, Lee County had 871 homeless people, a 2.7 percent increase from 2013.

"It's hard to tell if our homeless numbers have increased this year," said Janet Bartos, the executive director for the Lee County Homeless Coalition. "I hope it hasn't increased. But today, we're just hoping to alleviate some of their struggles if nothing else."

Coalition members surveyed everyone who attended the Homeless Service Day as part of its weeklong 2015 homeless count, and Bartos said her agency should reveal the statistics in several weeks. Bartos estimated at least 1,000 people attended Saturday's event, a larger crowd from 2014.
Tom Davis, 57, was one of the people who took advantage of the services. Davis picked up supplies and received a free haircut.

"I walked in and my hair was shaggy all the way down here," said Davis, pointing to his shoulders. "This is a benefit to everyone who is homeless. I'm a veteran so I don't need everything a lot of people are getting here."

About 400 volunteers assisted during the event. The Homeless Coalition paired each homeless person with a volunteer to walk them through the supply line to make sure they received all their needed supplies. FGCU sophomore Joshua Cordoba was one of about 30 FGCU students who helped.

Early in the morning, Cordoba was assigned to help a man in his 40s dressed in a dilapidated hoody sweatshirt and pants. The man didn't say much to Cordoba, but he did leave with five pairs of pants, shirts, toiletries and blankets.

Stack believes the majority of homeless are going through the same issues as him. Stack said his divorce, home foreclosure and the lack of being in his children's lives devastated him. Stack believes many homeless people are going through similar psychological issues.
"An event like this is great because it shows you, 'Hey, I'm not the only one who is out on the streets,'" Stack said. "It makes you feel like someone cares about you."
Jeb Bush's release this week of about 300,000 emails he wrote and received while in office from 1998-2006 stirred up interest that's already expanded to include privacy and technology matters.
The scope and detail of those emails is staggering. Bush's staff estimated he spent about 30 hours a week with them, and that's just his so-called personal account, not the executive office account.

Not only do they involve technical legislative issues, they came from individuals with problems including ill or delinquent children, bad neighbors and teachers, and business and personal relationships gone wrong — and many in painfully personal detail, regardless of the standard reminder that all emails are public record.
Bush himself replied to many more than you might think.

Florida's public records law makes all such mail public, and Bush's emails were regularly perused by Florida media. Now that he's eying the presidency, more such requests were certain. Some Social Security numbers escaped efforts to block them out, and Bush's staff has said they're working to correct that.

The sheer volume means it could take weeks to root through them all. Bush's website arranged them chronologically with the writer's header, but those headers are often general —such as "thank you," or "help needed," — with little hint of the issue.
Other groups posted batches of the emails with a rough search function, but self-describe it as "cumbersome."

That said, a few regarding Lee County matters and residents pop up. Bush has been out of office for years and some of his local correspondents are gone, and the issues long-settled — or not. They include:

• When Lee County schools changed start times and bus routes in the fall of 2002, Bush was deluged with angry emails from parents demanding the state step in and deal with the local school board. "I have not taken a position on this, but I think we should call and inquire about this to show some sensitivity to their plight," Bush wrote to an aide early on.

As the emails continued, Bush continued to respond that it was a local matter and the state had no say-so, although the responses grew shorter. "By law it is a local matter," he wrote. Emotions stayed high, with parents asking angrily if there was not something they or the state or feds could do.

"I guess there are two things people can do," Bush finally told one. Persuading local legislators to try to pass bills on the subject was first. "And voters can vote out their local school board members if they are not satisfied with local policies. Once again, thank you for writing."

• Bush knew former Lee County Commissioner Vicki Lopez-Lukis — at the time, Vicki Lopez-Wolfe — from their early days in Miami. After she was arrested in office and later released from detention, she wrote Bush in July 2004 about a delay with her executive clemency hearing and restoration of civil rights (rcr). "I will check with Wendy," an aide, Bush responded.

Wendy replied a few days later: "Governor, you requested that Mrs. Lukis's clemency application be expedited and I instructed the clemency office to do so. We thought, due to the nature of the offense, she would qualify for rcr without a hearing."
But the board was reluctant because of additional details on the case. "In light of the new information, do you still want the clemency board to expedite a hearing?" the aide asked Bush.
"Please explain to her the situation," Bush responded. "I would still support rcr for her." The ex-commissioner has since had her rights restored.

•Just after Bush's election, a voter asked him to call Lee County commissioners about a pending Boca Grande issue. On Jan. 1, 2003, he responded: "Patty, I just got to this email. I am getting inaugurated tomorrow and have a full day from 7 to 5 and won't be able to call. I hope it works out."

•In October 2003, Bush responded "That's great news!" to the South Florida Water Management District's announcement of plans to build a new reservoir near the Lee-Hendry County line that would hold water and help with pollution problems in the Calooshatchee River and Lake Okeechobee. Design was expected to start in 2006.
That land is now part of the proposed C43 reservoir site, which is still being debated.

•In November 2001, a Fort Myers man wrote Bush about problems with a tenant. The tenant had code and waste violations that were passed on to the property owner, and he — the owner — got no help or enforcement from local officials dealing with the tenant.

"I understand your concern", Bush wrote back, listing several state agencies, their numbers, and contact names the owner should try. "Sometimes these attempts are successful," Bush wrote. "Other times people must turn to the courts for resolution. Thank you for writing."

•In January 2001, Bush's staff heard from CBS executives, who said "60 Minutes" correspondent Scott Pelley would be in Tallahassee and would like 10 minutes for an off-the record chat. "Why? What's it about?" Bush asked his staff. "This is just a courtesy," explained a prescient aide. "And you never know, governor."
Rand Paul in Naples

U.S. Sen. Rand Paul will be in Naples for a "coffee and conversation" event at 9 a.m. Feb. 21 at Tiburon Golf Club. A $25 donation is specified; invitations say checks should be made out to "Rand Paul Victory Committee."

That's immediately preceded by another event from 8-9 a.m. at Naples' Ritz-Carlton Golf Resort , hosted by W.G. Eshbaugh Jr. MD. Admission there ranges from $250 to $2,700, with the money also going to Paul's victory committee.

U.S. Rep. Curt Clawson, R-Bonita Springs, is also expected to attend the later breakfast. Clawson made national news last month when he voted for Paul as House Speaker, mostly making a shout-out notice of Paul while protesting Rep. John Boehner's speakership. Paul responded on Twitter, asking "When do I start?'.

The tea party-aligned Kentucky senator is making all the moves of a presidential candidate, and he doesn't appear worried about competing on Jeb Bush's or Marco Rubio's home turf. Paul also has events in Sarasota and Orlando this weekend.
Fundraisers starting
All Lee County legislators up for election next year have opened campaign accounts, and state Rep. Heather Fitzenhagen is holding one of the first fundraisers.
Co-hosts include Eric and Brittany Cohill, David and Christin Collins, Jeff and Susan Garvin, Deborah Liftig, Kurt Maurillo, Scott Metzger and Tom and Elise Starr.
The event will be from 5:30-7:30 Feb. 25, at Gulf Harbour Country Club in south Fort Myers.
Betty Parker is a freelance writer specializing in politics. Her column appears in Saturday's The News-Press and on news-press.com.
Some of the biggest names in country music are coming to Charlotte County this weekend.
How big? So big, two of them just go by their first name: Hank and Reba.
Then you've got Charlie Daniels, Billy Currington, Big & Rich, Tracy Lawrence and about 12 other musical acts.
The three-day CountryLife Music Festival is probably the biggest music fest to ever hit Southwest Florida. And it's not the only super-sized fest happening this weekend.

Farther south, in Fort Myers, metalheads are getting ready for the third annual Fort Rock festival at JetBlue Park. The lineup includes hard-rocking superstars Slipknot, Papa Roach, Godsmack, Breaking Benjamin and 11 other bands.
Even more impressive: Both festivals are taking place near the end of April — a time when tourist season is winding down and entertainment options are drying up in Southwest Florida.

Festival organizers said they saw an untapped market of music fans just waiting for something fun to do. All it took was someone willing to risk spending hundreds of thousands of dollars — and sometimes $2 million or more — to book the bands and rent the venues.

"You gotta have a guy who's willing to take a chance," said CountryLife organizer Brad Maloney, owner of Illinois concert promoters Blu Events & Entertainment. "That's it. It's a gamble every time you put on a show. You gotta hope you sell enough tickets."
No problem here, it seems.
Both events are attracting huge amounts of people — many of them visiting Southwest Florida for the first time.

The annual Fort Rock has grown from about 10,000 people in 2013 to 15,000 for Saturday's sold-out event, said marketing director Clay Busch of Los Angeles concert promoters Danny Wimmer Presents. That's the maximum that JetBlue Park can hold, he added.

In Charlotte County, the new Florida Tracks & Trails outdoor adventure park expects to bring in about 20,000 people during the three-day event, which closes Sunday. And that number could double when the fest returns next year, said Florida Tracks & Trails marketing director Rachael Ketterman.

Once people see the park for themselves, she said, they'll want to come back. And they'll tell their friends, too. It's not just a concert venue. It's also an outdoor-recreation playland with a paintball park, a man-made lake and 22 miles of tracks and trails for dirt bikes, ATVs and other recreational vehicles.
"We're not a known location, relatively," Ketterman said. "We're really a theme park, and it's going to take guests coming to the site and seeing that for themselves. They'll be blown away."

Maloney said the improving Southwest Florida economy and expanding population were big factors for bringing CountryLife to Charlotte County. The event is a spin-off from its sister festival in Chillicothe, Ill.
"It's growing," he said about Southwest Florida. "Would we have done this five years ago? No. Clearly, we're bouncing back down here. The economy is bouncing back."
But there were other factors, too. Busch of Danny Wimmer Presents credited local rock stations 96 K-Rock and 93X.
The Los Angeles production company puts on the annual, two-day Welcome to Rockville fest in Jacksonville this weekend. Fort Rock features many of the same bands who will be playing that fest Sunday.

Danny Wimmer Presents was looking to expand its festival, and local radio stations helped clinch the deal. "We search for local festival markets," Busch said. "We look for great stations and influential stations. Those are two big factors to going into any market."
Radio stations rally support for Fort Rock, play the bands and get people excited about the fest, he said. That's why the company didn't put the festival in, say, Miami.
"You have two great rock stations in Fort Myers," Busch said. "You don't really get that in Miami."
Surprisingly, most of the music fans coming to Fort Rock and CountryLife aren't even from Southwest Florida.

About 70 percent of the Fort Rock audience travels there from Tampa, Miami and other cities outside Southwest Florida, Busch said. And CountryLife reports similar numbers: About 60 percent of ticket sales have come from people who live at least 50 to 60 miles away from Florida Tracks & Trails.
All those people are expected to generate a huge boost for the Southwest Florida economy this weekend.

"When people come into town, they're not just staying at hotels," said Sean Doherty, sales and sports marketing manager for the Charlotte Harbor Visitor & Convention Bureau. "They're also buying food, gas, you name it."
With those cash registers ringing loudly, Southwest Florida fans can expect the music to keep on playing in the coming years.
"Fort Rock isn't going anywhere," Busch said.

Neither is CountryLife. Maloney — a former Fort Myers resident who used to be vice president of operations for the Blu Sushi restaurant chain — said he signed a five-year deal with Florida Tracks & Trails.
And if people show their support for CountryLife, he said, he'll bring even bigger stars to Southwest Florida next year.

"If we get that kind of support... than we can get the Luke Bryans and the Garth Brookses and the Jason Aldeans," he said. "But if they don't come out and support us right now, we won't grow to that level."
IF YOU GO
•What: CountryLife Music Festival
•When: Friday through Sunday
•Where: Florida Tracks & Trails, 39450 Bermont Road, Charlotte County
•Tickets: Three-day passes for CountryLife are $139-$599 (including VIP packages). Single-day passes are $49-99.
•Info:countrylifemusicfestival.com
•Fort Rock is SOLD OUT
